fields.Title of Presentation: Theorizing Education: A Dialogue between Curriculum Studies, Philosophy and Allgemeine Pädagogik
fields.Conference/Meeting Name: ECER: Annual Meeting of the European Educational Research Association
fields.Sponsoring Organization: Department of Educational Policies, University of South Carolina
fields.Description/Abstract: This panel proposes to initiate a dialogue by focusing specifically on how representatives from these different nations define education, and how they understand their disciplines as having access to it. “In the English-speaking world,” as Gert Biesta has pointed out, education is understood as largely designating the world of formal learning (i.e. in schools, universities and other institutions). This in turn, is then “seen as a ‘field’ or ‘object’ of study and it is argued that in order to study this field of object we need input from a range of (proper) academic disciplines, most notably the psychology, history, sociology and philosophy of education.” Of course, words like utdanning (Norwegian) opleiding (Dutch) or Erziehung (German) designates both institutional education and that “education” that occurs through upbringing and non-specialized forms of engagement between adults and children. However, as Biesta emphasizes, what unifies this rather broad spectrum of activities for scholars working in these languages is “a distinctive educational concern that provides a particular way of looking at and engaging with educational phenomena.” To borrow from Schleiermacher, this interest is one that is defined by our answer to the question: “What do [we] the older generation actually want from the younger.”
